BIENNIAL REPORT
OF THB
SECKETABY OF STATE
OF THB
STATE OF NEBRASKA
FOR THE TWO YEARS ENDIN6 NOVEMBER 30, 1904
TO THE GOVERNOR
LINCOLN, NEB.:
JACOB NORTH * CO., PRINTERS
1904

To His Excellency, John H. Mickey, Governor of the State of Nebraska:
Sir— I have the honor to transmit herewith a report of this department for the two years ending November 30, 1904. The report as presented will be found to contain the business transactions of this office, together with a summary of the business transacted by the various boards of which I am a member. This report contains the appropriations for and the expenditures of this office, also a list of the corporations filing articles during the past biennium. I have omitted from this report the list of municipal and school bonds approved by me for the reason that the same appears in the report of the Auditor of Public Accounts. I have also omitted the certificates of approval of banks by the State Banking Board for the reason that the same appears in the report of the Banking Department; the list of notaries public commissioned has also been omitted. In making up this report I have endeavored to include only such matters as pertain to this office alone, omitting such items as have usually been found in this report, but which can be found in the reports of other departments, or which are not of any especial benefit to the public
Respectfully submitted,
Geo. W. Marsh,
Secretary of State.

SECRETARY OF STATE
15
To the Honorable Board of Public Lands and Buildings:
Gentlemen — I desire to submit the following report for the past blennium relative to the heating, water and plumbing systems of the Capitol building:
In the heating plant the four boilers have been reset. The 6-horse power boiler connected with the hoisting engine should be replaced by a new boiler of at least 10-horse power.
Two large steel tanks, of a capacity of 28,000 gallons, have been placed in the garret of the Capitol, thus completing the water system. The present water system is operated at the present time at a monthly expense of $13.70, as compared with an average expenditure of $100 per month for city water before the establishment of the water system.
The sewerage system has been greatly improved by the addition of four manholes and the connection of a 2-inch flush pipe. This will avoid the future stoppage of the sewer system, with its attendant inconvenience and expense.
Numerous minor repairs and improvements have been made in the engine house, the heating, water, gas, plumbing, and sewerage systems.
the greater portion of these alterations and repairs being performed without the employment of additional labor.
Respectfully submitted
TJ. G. SAWYER,
Engineer Capitol Building.
STATE ARCHITECT.
The legislature of 1903 passed an act creating the office of State Architect Pursuant to such act, on June 4, 1903, the Board of Public Lands and Buildings elected James Tyler, Jr., to such position. The act creating the office of State Architect provided that such architect should receive an annual salary of $2,500. and was authorized to appoint an assistant at an annual salary of $1,200, but failed to make appropriations for salaries or office expenses.
Following will be found a resume of the report of such Architect to the Board of Public Lands and Buildings:
The cost of maintenance of the office, inclusive of salary of Architect, assistant, stenographer, and office expenses, including necessary furniture and equipment, to November 30, 1904, was $8,004.08. Of this amount, cash to the amount of $353.06 has been advanced by the State Architect In the payment of various necessary expenditures.
The Architect has drawn plans for, or supervised, or both, work for various state institutions, the expenditures for which have been, in round numbers, $273,000. The cost to the state for these services, had private architects been retained, would have amounted to $13,500. From this

16
REPORT OP THE
it would Appear that the creation of the office has not only been a great saying to the state, but the services of an architect were always at the command of the board for slight alterations and repairs, for which professional advice would not have been sought previous to the creation of the office. In addition, the matter of repairs and improvements to the various institutions have been reduced to a systematic basis for the future, all plans and specifications being assembled in a state office, rather than scattered promiscuously through the offices of various archi
Indicative of the amount of work done is the fact that 554 sheets of plans have been drawn, and in addition thereto 236 sheets of details, while specifications have been drawn for 96 various new constructions and improvements. All repairs at the various institutions have been made under the supervision of the Architect.
Following will be found a brief and specific account of the s< rendered to, and future needs of the various institutions.
Norfolk Hospital for Insane. — Plans and specifications were drawn for the administration building, three cottages, waterworks, and building grounds. It is recommended that the old building, destroyed by fire, be repaired by taking off the top story, at an estimated cost of $18,800. That the tunnel be extended to the various buildings, and that the steam, water, and electrical systems be remodeled at an estimated cost of $14,600. That another cottage, at the estimated cost of $26,500, be
Eloldiers' and Sailors' Home, Milford. — Plans and specifications have drawn for the new hospital, boiler house, and waterworks, in addito a large amount of repairs to the existing structures. i For the lg biennium provision should be made for a laundry building, addito hospital, repairs to plumbing, and additional fire protection.
E Soldiers' and Sailors' Home, Grand Island. — A new commissar}' and dry building have been erected under the plans and superintendence le Architect; also a general overhauling of the water, lighting, and ibing systems, and a large amount of general repairs. The future Is of the institution seem to require the erection of a new coal shed, itructed of brick, at an estimated cost of $1,500; a new roof on the W house and new boiler, at an estimated cost of $3,900. The reeling of the sewerage system is imperative, at an estimated cost of )0; also repainting various buildings, at an estimated cost of t-
Bastings Asylum. — A new barn, waterworks, and electrical system added to the previous equipment, In addition to various repairs.
Lincoln Asylum. — A new barn and greenhouse have been erected.
¦ipitol Building. — Plans and specifications were drawn for the stone and walks erected at the approaches to the grounds.
Penitentiary. — Plans and specifications were drawn for altering the steam plant and for the system of new steel cells installed, the work on construction being done by architects employed previous to the creation of the office of State Architect

17
Institute for Feeble Minded Youth. — The kitchen has been remodeled and a cold storage plant erected. The cold storage plant not being completed, owing to lack of funds, to complete this building will cost, approximately, $800. A boys' dormitory and also a school building and gymnasium combined should be added.
Boys' Industrial School. — Plans and specifications for new tunnel were drawn, but not used. A. new boiler was installed, and a large amount of general repairs were put in. A new boiler, electrical power for the workshops, rearrangement of heating plant, repairs to tunnel, and new boiler for greenhouse are the immediate needs.
Girls' Industrial School. — Only general repairs have been made at this institution. A new boiler should be added, boiler house enlarged, and additional height given to the chimney, at an estimated cost of $2,500. General repairs to the extent of at least $1,000 should be mad*.
yDeaf and Dumb Institute. — A new building should be added, at an nated cost of $18,000.
STATE PRINTING BOARD.
During the biennium of 1903-4 the State Printing Board ha« secured bids upon and awarded contracts for many hundreds of .dollars' worth of miscellaneous printing and stationery supplies for the different departments and institutions operating under the state government While the volume of this business makes It impractical to submit here a detailed statement thereof, the records of the board give tangible and indisputable proof that the numerous small items have been purchased by this method at a net reduction in cost from 25 to 50 per cent, as compared with the prices previously and customarily paid.
Kr each letting a tabulated schedule Is prepared, giving foil Inion regarding items, bidders, prices, and awards, the same being red as a portion of the records of the board.
Throughout the biennium competition has been unusually keen, with the result that, notwithstanding the uniformly high cost of labor and material, the state has secured a much greater value for the money expended for printing than in any previous period. The number of bidders has averaged from twelve to twenty.
The board has recently purchased a set of the most accurate paper testing devices, including testers for strength, thickness, and weight, by the use of which the state is insured full value in material on every contract, and the contractors are protected from suffering any injustice through unreasonable objections.
The printing board suggests that the best Interests of the state would be served by the purchase, annually, of a bulk stock of staple stationery supplies, including pens, pencils, writing fluid, mucilage, library paste, erasers, rubber bands, typewriter and mimeograph supplies, blotters, etc., the same to be Issued to the different departments and Institu-
te

REPORT OF THE
18
tions on requisition. There is no question that this method would be roost economical in time and money, and greatly reduce the annoyance which has frequently occurred under the present system. It is also recommended that the printing board should be given more power in the matter of emergency printing.

REPORT OF THE
Following will be found some comparisons of prices paid for annual reports, etc.:
400 Building and Loan Association reports 1900, 144 pages at $4.50. (648; 1901, 160 pages at $1.08, $172.80; 1902, 160 pages at $3.50, $561.60; 1904, 157 pages at 871-4 cents, $140.50. 500 copies 1903, 160 pages at $1.29, $206.40.
BIO reports Banking Department 1900, 208 pages at $3.40, $707.20; copies 1902, 272 pages at $2.40, $651.84; 1903, 312 pages at $1.38. 6; 1904, 312 pages at 91 cents, $283.92.
B000 Agricultural reports 1900, 404 pages at 3.15, $1,385.06; 1901, 310 at $2.72, $859.20; 1902, 404 pages at $2.65, $1,070.60; 1903, 408 at $2.65, $1,081.20; 1904, 404 pages at $2.55, $1,030.20.
5,000 Horticultural reports 1900, 304 pages at $3, $1,003.01; 1901, 304 pages at $2.80, $851.20; 1902, 308 pages at $3.80, $1,170.40; 1903. 308 pages at $2.55, $785.40; 1904, 276 pages at $2.33. $643.08.
1,000 Supreme Court calendars 1900, 500 pages at $1.58, $790; 800 copies, 1900, 560 pages at $1.58, $884.80; 1902, 196 pages at $0.80, $156.80; 1903, 170 pages at 64 cents, $108.44; 1904, 167 pages at 65 cents, $108.55.
10,000 Labor Bulletins 1902, 250 pages, $990.16; 15,000 same 1904, 200 pages, $822.14.
R'omputation will show that in 1900 reports of Building and Loan Nation. Banking Department, Agricultural, and Horticultural Socleind Supreme Court calendars cost, in round numbers, $4,333. In the same publications cost $3,611, while in 1904 the expense was $2,206. Saving over 1900, $2,127; saving over 1902, $1,405.
